ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how different pieces of literature interacted with various political movements in America and Europe throughout the 20th century. I also learned how to place archival materials in their historical and aesthetic context.

This course invited me to think more deeply about the relationship between art (specifically, works of literature  poems & novels, many of which I encountered for the first time) and various "cultural revolutions" of the twentieth century,

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Fascinating syllabus that introduces students to a host of important but not mainstream literary/aesthetic movements Weaknesses: Too much reading, hard to know what we were supposed to focus on--some weeks the political manifestos were more important, other weeks it was only the novels; need more historical background on each piece of art before discussion; more organized lectures at the beginning of class

The syllabus for this class is excellent; Tim is extremely knowledgeable about the works he's assigned and their broader cultural context and legacy. He's a very involved and conscientious instructor. I really enjoyed our discussions in seminar. The course was a mix of class years which I was worried about at first but which I think wound up working out well. I loved the fact that half the course meetings were devoted to the study and discussion of relevant archival materials at the Beinecke. I also appreciated the flexibility of the syllabus (the extra weeks for the works of Peter Weiss & Frantz Fanon, for example), though the last couple weeks wound up feeling as though they were thrown a bit off balance as a result. I would say the class was slightly disorganized but not to the detriment of my learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any humanities student who is interested in the 20th century and the relationship between art and politics. This course has A TON of potential. It is a dream syllabus for many avid humanities students. However, this course needs to be much more organized and structured and redesigned for it to be successful.

I would  anyone interested in the question of if and how art can be used to further social and cultural movements would be well-served by studying the texts on this syllabus, and Tim is excellent at facilitating engaging conversations about and with these texts.

extras.title: HUMS 182 01 - Art in the Age of Revolt
